history.content:
"If you care about fast code, write C code. But, it's really assembly all the way down. Well, it's really bits on a wire all the way down."

I think if you're planning to spend your life doing and loving CS, this is knowledge you really deserve to experience for yourself at some point.

anon2's advice: 

it's pretty important. it teaches you how a computer works. this is stuff that self-taught programmers never learn. this is the stuff that separates programmers from computer scientists.

It's important for cs15x classes and cs162

it's definitely not common sense stuff.

"If you care about fast code, write C code. But, it's really assembly all the way down. Well, it's really bits on a wire all the way down."

I think if you're planning to spend your life doing and loving CS, this is knowledge you really deserve to experience for yourself at some point.

children.subject:
this is actually a good discussion to have. As you may imagine, everyone has a different opinion, usually corresponding to how their experience in the class went.

I'm taking 61c right now and will tell you that it's nothing like 61A or 61B and far less enjoyable. It's probably because I know I'll never actually get into hardware or machine architecture as a career. But as anon2 from the answer above says, it gives you the knowledge of understanding the whole versus the parts - very well said that "this is the stuff that separates programmers from computer scientists."

So if you don't have to take it, well, audit the class or take it and drop it later if you don't end up liking it, or if you feel you can just review the lecture slides/webcasts to get a surface-level overview.

also, to answer your question, it is not very practical unless you are either very interested in machine architecture and hardware (building circuits and very low level, like assembly language) or planning a career in machine architecture. It just gives you a good overview of machine architecture as a whole which you would not learn in any other lower-div CS course.

To give a slightly different perspective: I took 61c a few semesters ago and thought I'd never use it again. However, even for practical programming, some of what we learn (especially about cache locality) is quite useful if you're writing performance-critical applications. Definitely not anywhere near as useful in practice as 61A, 61B, or 170; however, not completely useless.
actually i don't feel like 170 is really that practical.....i rarely use the algorithms taught in 170. am i just not a rockstar programmer yet?

It's more about the ability to create an algorithm than copying the algorithms in 170. Creating algorithms and analyzing runtimes is reasonably important! But it definitely depends on what sorts of things you're programming for.
At least 170 teaches you how to think about certain stuff, while 61C mostly talks about hardware that won't really matter if you are not going into that stuff.

+1 170 is one of those "must-take" courses if you want to call yourself a computer scientist. Again, there's that gap between self-taught programmers from Codecademy and computer scientists from an institution like MIT, Berkeley, Stanford, etc.

It's probably true that most of the time you will not use material from either 70/170 or 61C/152 directly, since lots of these things are essentially abstracted away by libraries and compilers. The real point of these classes is to teach you how to think in terms of algorithms and systems respectively. The best algorithm in the world will be useless if it can't be mapped to hardware and the best hardware is useless if it can't run any useful algorithms. You need both to be a "rockstar."
Well, does that mean that other than pedagogical reasons, it is not much of use speaking of practicality?

history.content:
As question says, how important is 61C?

I've heard some ppl say they have never saw most stuff from 61C every again in upper divs, and some say differently.

Are the materials from 61C important for upper divs? If so, what classes?

Or is it just one of those common sense stuff?
history.subject: How important is 61C?
